content:
Record date: 2088-07-03

Team 1 Intern Admission Note



Name: Younger, T Eugene

MR#: 6381987

Att: Dr. Gilbert

Cards: Dr. Ullrich

Neuro: Dr. Donovan

Date of Admission: 7/2/88



CC: Lightheadedness, vertigo, and presyncopal sx x several episodes



HPI:. 64 yoM w/ significant PMH for CAD, HTN, GERD, and past cerebral embolism presents w/ 6 hour history of vertiginous symptoms, dizziness, lightheadedness, and feeling "like [he] was going to pass out".  The pt recalls waking and getting ready for work.  He then began having short episodes of vertiginous attacks in which he felt the room was "constantly going out of focus" and inability to "lock in on any one thing".  The pt had several episodes of these presyncopal attacks w/o LOC.  The pt had no associated CP or palpitations, however noted some increased rate of breathing.  The pt also noted some reflux sx a/w attacks.  He denies f/c, ns, d/c, diploplia/photophobia.  Had associated nausea without vomiting as well as tinnitus, which he usually has.  Attacks began to affect driving so he presented to EW.



Pt has one prior episode similar to this experience in 2082, for which he received imaging studies including CT of the head, MRI/MRA, TCDs which revealed no infarcts, but poor flow in the mid-basilar artery.  TTE at that time showed an intra-atrial septal aneurysm.  



ROS: +tinnitus, -weakness/change in sensation, ataxia, aura-like sx, post-episode confusion

	+ anorexia, nausea

 

PMH: 

CAD: 2075 PTCA w/ Angioplasty to LAD, Stress (3/88): rev. anterolateral ischemia, Cath (5/88): 3v disease: RCA 90%, LAD 30% mid, 80% distal, D1 70%, D2 40% and 60%, LCx 30%, OM2 80% 

HTN

Hypercholesterolemia

GERD

H/O cerebral embolism (2082)

H/O intra-arterial septal aneurysm



Meds: 

Atenolol 25/50mg qAM/qPM

ASA 325mg qD

Prilosec 20mg qD

Lipitor 10mg qD

NTG sl prn: last used several months ago as a "test"



ALL: NKDA, Intolerance to Inderal



FHx: 

+ HTN: mother /brother

+DM: mother

+MI: father



Soc Hx: Lives by himself separated.  Works as Economist.

+ EtOH: 1-2 beers/wk, -tobacco



PE:

VS:

Gen: Well-nourished male, NAD

HEENT: MMM, OP clear

Neck: JVP about 9 cm.  

Chest: Clear to ausc. B/L

CV:  + S1, S2 regular. +S4

Extremity: warm, well-perfused

Neuro: AAO x 3, CNIs: lateral beating nystagmus.  Motor/strength grossly intact. Good Rapid alteranting movements.  F-t-N intact.  Negative rombeg's  sight.



LABS: 

Lytes/Renal/Glucose

Sodium                 140   135-145 mmol/L     07/02/88 11:21     147(H) 10/08/82 13:24            

Potassium              4.1   3.4-4.8 mmol/L     07/02/88 11:21                                      

Chloride               105   100-108 mmol/L     07/02/88 11:21                                      

Carbon Dioxide        29.3   24.0-30.0 mmol/L   07/02/88 11:21    33.1(H) 08/02/87 12:40            

Blood Urea Nitro        12   8-25 mg/dl         07/02/88 11:21                                      

Creatinine             1.0   0.6-1.5 mg/dl      07/02/88 11:21                                      

Glucose                157H  70-110 mg/dl       07/02/88 11:21     157(H) 07/02/88 11:21            

General Chemistries

Calcium                9.2   8.5-10.5 mg/dl     07/02/88 13:06                                      

Phosphorus             2.1L  2.6-4.5 mg/dl      07/02/88 13:06     2.1(L) 07/02/88 13:06            

Magnesium              1.7   1.4-2.0 meq/L      07/02/88 13:06                                      

Total Protein          8.4H  6.0-8.0 g/dl       07/02/88 13:06     8.4(H) 07/02/88 13:06            

Albumin                4.2   3.1-4.3 g/dl       07/02/88 13:06                                      

Globulin               4.2H  2.6-4.1 g/dl       07/02/88 13:06     4.2(H) 07/02/88 13:06            

ALT (SGPT)              38   10-55 U/L          07/02/88 13:06      79(H) 04/05/88 12:16            

AST (SGOT)              36   10-40 U/L          07/02/88 13:06      62(H) 04/05/88 12:16            

Alkaline Phospha       111   45-115 U/L         07/02/88 13:06                                      

Total Bilirubin        0.5   0-1.0 mg/dl        07/02/88 13:06                                      

Direct Bilirubin       0.2   0-0.4 mg/dl        07/02/88 13:06                                      

Bili Conjugated       0.00   0-0.30 mg/dl       04/05/88 12:16                                      

Bili Unconjugate       0.8   0-2.5 mg/dl        04/05/88 12:16                                      

Cardiac Tests

CPK                     91   60-400 U/L         07/02/88 21:50                                      

CK-MB QUANT            1.5   0.0-6.9 ng/ml      07/02/88 22:12                                      

LDH                    222H  110-210 U/L        03/15/85 21:55     222(H) 03/15/85 21:55            

Troponin-I        NEGATIVE   NEG                07/02/88 11:24                                      

Troponin-T           <0.01   0.00-0.09 ng/ml    07/02/88 22:12

Lipoprotein (a)          0   LESS THAN 34 MG/   07/09/79 08:48                                      

Thyroid Studies

Chemistry Miscellaneous

Hematology

Complete Blood Count

HCT                   43.5   41.0-53.0 %        07/02/88 11:33    41.6(L) 04/05/88 12:02            

MHCT                    41   M42-52; F37-48 %   07/28/78 20:49                                      

HGB                   15.8   13.5-17.5 gm/dl    07/02/88 11:33    13.1(L) 03/15/85 20:15            

RBC                   5.14   4.50-5.90 mil/cm   07/02/88 11:33    4.48(L) 06/08/83 22:03            

PLT                    194   150-350 th/cumm    07/02/88 11:33                                      

MCV                     85   80-100 fl          07/02/88 11:33      85(L) 04/11/83 19:46            

MCH                   30.7   26.0-34.0 pg/rbc   07/02/88 11:33                                      

MCHC                  36.3   31.0-37.0 g/dl     07/02/88 11:33                                      

RDW                   12.8   11.5-14.5 %        07/02/88 11:33                                      

Blood Differential %

Differential Req  RECEIVED                      07/02/88 11:08                                      

Diff Method           Auto                      07/02/88 11:33                                      

Neutrophils             70   40-70 %            07/02/88 11:33                                      

Lymphocytes             23   22-44 %            07/02/88 11:33                                      

Monocytes                4   4-11 %             07/02/88 11:33                                      

Eosinophils              2   0-8 %              07/02/88 11:33                                      

Basophils                1   0-3 %              07/02/88 11:33                                      

Neutrophils - Au        68   40-70 %            11/23/83 17:08                                      

Lymphocytes - Au        20L  22-44 %            11/23/83 17:08      20(L) 11/23/83 17:08            

Monocytes - Auto         9   4-11 %             11/23/83 17:08                                      

Eosinophils - Au         2   0-8 %              11/23/83 17:08                                      

Basophils - Auto         1   0-3 %              11/23/83 17:08                                      

Neutrophils - Ma        65   45-74 %            06/21/79 22:01                                      

Lymphocytes - Ma        27   16-45 %            06/21/79 22:01                                      

Monocytes - Manu         8   4-10 %             06/21/79 22:01                                      

Eosinophils - Ma         0   0-7 %              06/21/79 22:01                                      

Basophils - Manu         0   0-2 %              06/21/79 22:01                                      

Blood Diff - Absolute

Abs Neuts             4.48   1.8-7.7 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                      

Abs Lymphs            1.47   1.0-4.8 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                      

Abs Monos             0.23   0.2-0.4 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                      

Abs Eos               0.14   0.1-0.3 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                      

Abs Basos             0.05   0.0-0.3 th/cmm     07/02/88 11:33                                     

Routine Coagulation

PT                    12.7   11.1-13.1 sec      07/02/88 11:21                                      

PT-INR                 1.1                      07/02/88 11:21                                      

PTT                   24.4   22.1-35.1 sec      07/02/88 11:21                                      



EKG:  Sinus brady @ 60, w/ LAD, ICVD (QRS 108), NS St/T wave changes. Stable eDk

 

CXR:  Pending



Impression:  64 yo male w/ significant CAD, past cerebral emboli, presents w/ sx c/w VBI vs. peripheral vertio.  Would like to r/o progression of atherosclerotic/new embolic disease in posterior circulation, giver clinical exam and history.  



Plan:

1.	Vertigo: Clinically peripheral disease.  If central, would not expect to be affected by motion, be able to be eextinguished, etc.  

Fall precautions

R/o cardiac ischemia: Troponins, monitor, etc

Consult neurology, Dr. Donovan in am to evaluate pt

Ordered MRA, TCDs, and  other non-invasive studies of circulation

Cont ASA 325mg qD



2.	CAD: Cont ASA, B-blockade, (with parameters) and statin. Restart ARB, per Dr. Ullrich.

3.	HTN: controlled w/ above

4.	General care:  Nexium, pt ambulating; Full diet, cardiac prudent.











Betty Kaitlin Wood, MD

# 69981

**Summary of Medical History**

Patient: Younger, T Eugene
Age: 64 years old
Sex: Male

**Chief Complaint:** Vertigo, lightheadedness, and presyncopal symptoms for 6 hours

**History of Present Illness:** Patient woke up with symptoms of vertigo, dizziness, and lightheadedness. He experienced multiple episodes of brief vertiginous attacks, with a sense of the room spinning and difficulty focusing. Symptoms were accompanied by nausea, tinnitus, and increased heart rate. Patient denied any loss of consciousness, chest pain, or neurological deficits.

**Past Medical History:**

* Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
* Hypertension (HTN)
* Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
* Past cerebral embolism (2082)
* Intra-arterial septal aneurysm

**Medications:**

* Atenolol 25/50mg qAM/qPM
* Aspirin 325mg qD
* Prilosec 20mg qD
* Lipitor 10mg qD
* Nitroglycerin sublingual (SL) PRN (last used several months ago)

**Family History:**

* Mother: HTN, Diabetes Mellitus (DM)
* Father: Myocardial Infarction (MI)
* Brother: HTN

**Social History:**

* Lives alone, separated
* Works as an economist
* Occasional alcohol consumption (1-2 beers/week)
* No tobacco use

**Physical Examination:**

* General: Well-nourished male, normal mental status
* HEENT: Normal
* Neck: JVP 9 cm
* Chest: Clear to auscultation
* CV: Regular rhythm, S1, S2, S4 sounds present
* Extremities: Warm, well-perfused
* Neurological: AAO x 3, CNIs: lateral beating nystagmus, motor strength grossly intact

**Laboratory Results:**

* Electrolytes: Within normal limits
* Renal function: Within normal limits
* Glucose: Elevated (157 mg/dL)
* Cardiac enzymes: CK-MB, LDH within normal limits
* Lipid profile: Cholesterol elevated (162 mg/dL), Triglycerides elevated (307 mg/dL)
* Thyroid function tests: Within normal limits
* Complete Blood Count (CBC): Within normal limits

**Imaging Studies:**

* ECG: Sinus bradycardia, left axis deviation, nonspecific ST/T wave changes
* CXR: Pending

**Impression:**

* 64-year-old male with significant CAD, past cerebral emboli, presenting with symptoms concerning for vertebral basilar insufficiency (VBI) versus peripheral vertigo.
* Plan to rule out progression of atherosclerotic or new embolic disease in the posterior circulation.

**Plan:**

1. Vertigo: Clinically peripheral disease. If central, would not expect to be affected by motion, be able to be extinguished, etc.
* Fall precautions
* Rule out cardiac ischemia: Troponins, monitor, etc
* Consult neurology, Dr. Donovan in the morning to evaluate patient
* Ordered MRA, TCDs, and other non-invasive studies of circulation
* Continue aspirin 325mg qD

2. CAD: Continue aspirin, beta-blockade, and statin. Restart ARB, per Dr. Ullrich.

3. HTN: Controlled with above medications.

4. General care: Nexium, patient ambulating, full diet, cardiac prudent.

Betty Kaitlin Wood, MD

# 69981

**Summary of Medical History Related to Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)**

Patient: T Eugene Younger

Age: 64 years old

Chief Complaint: Vertigo, lightheadedness, and presyncopal symptoms

Past Medical History:

* Significant CAD with:
	+ Previous PTCA with angioplasty to LAD
	+ Stress test showing anterolateral ischemia
	+ Catheterization showing 3-vessel disease:
		- RCA: 90%
		- LAD: 30% mid, 80% distal
		- D1: 70%
		- D2: 40% and 60%
		- LCx: 30%
		- OM2: 80%
* Hypertension (HTN)
* Hypercholesterolemia
* Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
* History of cerebral embolism (2082)
* Intra-arterial septal aneurysm

Medications:

* Aspirin (ASA) 325mg qD
* Atenolol 25/50mg qAM/qPM
* Prilosec 20mg qD
* Lipitor 10mg qD
* Nitroglycerin (NTG) SL prn (last used several months ago as a "test")

Laboratory Results:

* Elevated troponin levels (222H)
* Elevated CK-MB QUANT (1.5)
* Elevated LDH (222H)
* Elevated triglycerides (307H)
* Low HDL (9L)
* High LDL (123)
* Cardiac risk ratio (4.50)

Imaging Studies:

* ECG showing sinus bradycardia with left axis deviation and nonspecific ST/T wave changes
* CXR pending

Impressions:

* CAD with possible progression of atherosclerotic disease in the posterior circulation
* Possible new embolic disease in the posterior circulation
* Peripheral vertigo likely due to clinically peripheral disease

Plan:

* Continue aspirin therapy
* Consult neurology to evaluate patient
* Order MRA, TCDs, and other non-invasive studies of circulation
* Restart ARB per Dr. Ullrich
* Continue statin therapy
* Control hypertension with medication
* Provide general care, including Nexium and full diet.

Record date: 2088-07-03

Team 1 Intern Admission Note



Name: Younger, T Eugene

MR#: 6381987

Att: Dr. Gilbert

Cards: Dr. Ullrich

Neuro: Dr. Donovan

Date of Admission: 7/2/88



CC: Lightheadedness, vertigo, and presyncopal sx x several episodes



HPI:. 64 yoM w/ significant PMH for CAD, HTN, GERD, and past cerebral embolism presents w/ 6 hour history of vertiginous symptoms, dizziness, lightheadedness, and feeling "like [he] was going to pass out".  The pt recalls waking and getting ready for work.  He then began having short episodes of vertiginous attacks in which he felt the room was "constantly going out of focus" and inability to "lock in on any one thing".  The pt had several episodes of these presyncopal attacks w/o LOC.  The pt had no associated CP or palpitations, however noted some increased rate of breathing.  The pt also noted some reflux sx a/w attacks.  He denies f/c, ns, d/c, diploplia/photophobia.  Had associated nausea without vomiting as well as tinnitus, which he usually has.  Attacks began to affect driving so he presented to EW.



Pt has one prior episode similar to this experience in 2082, for which he received imaging studies including CT of the head, MRI/MRA, TCDs which revealed no infarcts, but poor flow in the mid-basilar artery.  TTE at that time showed an intra-atrial septal aneurysm.

	+ anorexia, nausea

HTN

# 69981

**Summary of Medical History**

Patient: T Eugene Younger

Age: 64 years old

Chief Complaint: Vertigo, lightheadedness, and presyncopal symptoms

Past Medical History:

* Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
* Hypertension
* Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
* Past cerebral embolism (2082)
* Intra-arterial septal aneurysm

Medications:

* Atenolol 25/50mg qAM/qPM
* Aspirin 325mg qD
* Prilosec 20mg qD
* Lipitor 10mg qD
* Nitroglycerin sublingual as needed

Laboratory Results:

* Elevated glucose levels (157 mg/dL)
* Elevated triglycerides (307 mg/dL)
* Low HDL cholesterol (9 mg/dL)
* Elevated LDL cholesterol (123 mg/dL)
* Cardiac risk ratio is high (20.67)

Imaging Studies:

* Chest X-ray pending
* Electrocardiogram (EKG) shows sinus bradycardia with left axis deviation and nonspecific ST/T wave changes

Impressions:

* Possible vertebral basilar insufficiency (VBI) versus peripheral vertigo
* Need to rule out progression of atherosclerotic or new embolic disease in the posterior circulation

Plan:

1. Fall precautions due to possible vertigo
2. Rule out cardiac ischemia with troponins and monitoring
3. Consult neurology to evaluate patient
4. Order MRA, TCDs, and other non-invasive studies of circulation
5. Continue aspirin, beta-blockade, and statin therapy
6. Restart angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) as per Dr. Ullrich
7. Control hypertension with medication
8. Provide general care, including Nexium, full diet, and cardiac precautions.

# 69981

This is a comprehensive medical record from 2088, detailing the admission and treatment of a 64-year-old male patient, Mr. Eugene Younger, with a complex medical history.

**Chief Complaint:** Mr. Younger presents with a 6-hour history of vertiginous symptoms, including dizziness, lightheadedness, and feeling "like he was going to pass out." These symptoms have been recurring over the past few days, affecting his ability to drive.

**Past Medical History:**

* Coronary Artery Disease (CAD)
* Hypertension
* Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
* Past cerebral embolism (2082)
* Intra-arterial septal aneurysm

**Medications:**

* Atenolol 25/50mg qAM/qPM
* Aspirin 325mg qD
* Prilosec 20mg qD
* Lipitor 10mg qD
* Nitroglycerin sublingual (SL) PRN (last used several months ago)

**Physical Examination:**

* Vital signs: stable
* Neurological examination: normal except for lateral beating nystagmus
* Cardiovascular examination: normal except for S4 heart sound

**Laboratory Results:**

* Electrolyte panel: within normal limits
* Complete blood count: within normal limits
* Liver function tests: mildly elevated AST and ALT
* Lipid profile: high cholesterol and triglycerides
* Thyroid function tests: normal
* Cardiac enzymes: normal

**Imaging Studies:**

* Chest X-ray: pending
* ECG: shows sinus bradycardia with left axis deviation and nonspecific ST/T wave changes

**Impression:**

The admitting physician suspects Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency (VBI) versus peripheral vertigo. Given the patient's history of CAD, past cerebral embolism, and current symptoms, it is essential to rule out progression of atherosclerotic or new embolic disease in the posterior circulation.

**Plan:**

1. **Vertigo:** Clinically peripheral disease. If central, would not expect to be affected by motion, be able to be extinguished, etc.
	* Fall precautions
	* Rule out cardiac ischemia: troponins, monitor, etc
	* Consult neurology, Dr. Donovan, in the morning to evaluate the patient
	* Order MRA, TCDs, and other non-invasive studies of circulation
	* Continue aspirin 325mg qD
2. **CAD:** Continue aspirin, beta-blockade, and statin. Restart ARB, per Dr. Ullrich.
3. **HTN:** Controlled with above medications
4. **General care:** Nexium, patient ambulating, full diet, cardiac prudent

Overall, the plan involves ruling out central causes of vertigo, managing the patient's CAD, hypertension, and GERD, and providing general care to prevent further complications.
